questions.text: A 4-week-old infant is brought to the physician by his mother because of blood-tinged stools for 3 days. He has also been passing whitish mucoid strings with the stools during this period. He was delivered at 38 weeks' gestation by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. He was monitored in the intensive care unit for a day prior to being discharged. His 6-year-old brother was treated for viral gastroenteritis 1 week ago. The patient is exclusively breastfed. He is at the 50th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. He appears healthy and active. His vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. A stool test for occult blood is positive. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes and creatinine are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Assess for IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies
Continue breastfeeding and advise mother to avoid dairy and soy products
Stop breastfeeding and switch to soy-based formula
Perform an air enema on the infant

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An upper gastrointestinal series may be indicated for suspected volvulus. Although volvulus may cause bloody stools in an infant, it typically also manifests with vomiting, hemodynamic instability, and abdominal distention. This infant does not present with these associated symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

The IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibody test is highly sensitive and specific for celiac disease (CD). CD may manifest in infancy, but the usual age of onset is 8–12 months of age (i.e., 2–3 months following the introduction of gluten to the diet). Typical symptoms include steatorrhea and signs of malabsorption (e.g., vitamin deficiencies, anemia, failure to thrive), none of which this patient has. Moreover, CD does not typically cause gastrointestinal bleeding.

C) CORRECT:

This child presents with new-onset passage of blood and mucus with no signs of obstruction (e.g., abdominal distention) or systemic illness (e.g., vomiting, diarrhea, fever, hypotension). This constellation of symptoms in an exclusively breastfed infant suggests food protein-induced proctocolitis due to a non-IgE-mediated immune response to food antigens in the mother's milk. Diagnosis of this condition is clinical and management should begin with elimination of all dairy and soy products from the mother's diet. If symptoms continue, egg products should then be eliminated. Continued breastfeeding is encouraged as long as the offending proteins can be avoided. Formula-fed infants with food protein-induced proctocolitis should be switched to hydrolyzed formulas (e.g., hydrolyzed casein).

Rectal bleeding usually improves within 3 days of removal of the offending food antigen. Most infants will be able to tolerate reintroduction of the offending food antigen to their diet by the time they are 1 year old.

D) INCORRECT:

A stool antigen immunoassay may be used for the diagnosis of Helicobacter pylori infection. This infection is associated with peptic ulcer disease, which typically manifests later in life with upper abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, and often vomiting. Stool antigen immunoassay would therefore not be helpful in the workup for passage of blood and mucus in this healthy-looking 4-week-old infant.

E) INCORRECT:

Breastfeeding is strongly recommended as the preferred source of nutrition for all infants due to its numerous health benefits for both the infant and the mother. Consequently, changing to a formula-based diet would not be an appropriate initial step in the management of this patient. Additionally, soy antigens are one of the most common causes of food protein-induced proctocolitis. Switching to a soy-based formula could exacerbate this patient's colitis. Formula-fed infants with food protein-induced proctocolitis should be switched to hydrolyzed formulas (e.g., hydrolyzed casein).

F) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum parenteral antibiotics may be administered for the treatment of necrotizing enterocolitis, which manifests with abdominal distention, blood-tinged stools, and systemic signs of illness (i.e., vomiting, diarrhea, fever, hypotension) in a preterm infant. Although this patient has bloody stools, he was born at full-term and appears healthy and active.

G) INCORRECT:

Air enema would be an appropriate step in the management of suspected intussusception. Hallmark findings of intussusception are acute cyclical, cramping abdominal pain, and vomiting. Although this patient presents with blood-tinged stools, which is a late finding in intussusception, the lack of vomiting, abdominal pain, or a palpable abdominal mass make diet-associated colitis more likely. Moreover, intussusception is uncommon in infants < 3 months of age.
questions.hint: The presence of blood-tinged stools in an otherwise active and healthy infant raises concern for food protein-induced proctocolitis.

questions.text: A previously healthy 35-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation because of an episode of shortness of breath and swollen lips 2 weeks ago. He was dining with his friends at a seafood restaurant, where they ordered the "all you can eat" menu. Ten minutes after he started eating, he noticed a swelling of the lips, wheezing, and shortness of breath. His friends called 911 and he had to be transported to the emergency department for treatment and close observation after this episode. Today, his temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A skin prick test shows a positive result for salmon (7 mm) and cod (4 mm); there is no reactivity to shrimp. The patient enjoys eating seafood and wonders whether he can continue to eat other types of fish in the future. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation?

choices.text: Take antihistamines one hour before eating fish
Inject intramuscular norepinephrine after eating fish
Reduce the daily dietary amount of fish

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral antihistamines can be used to treat mild allergic reactions such as urticaria, oral itch, or mild abdominal pain. This patient, however, had an anaphylactic reaction, for which treatment with antihistamines is insufficient. Furthermore, there is no recommendation that supports pretreatment with antihistamines in patients with IgE-mediated food allergies (e.g., fish allergy).

B) CORRECT:

Complete avoidance of the food allergen and similar foods is the preferred management for patients with food allergies. Although this patient's skin prick test is positive only for salmon and cod, he should also avoid all other types of finned fish because of a high risk of cross-reactivity. In addition, he should be counseled on cross-contacts (e.g., in restaurants), food allergens in unexpected sources or nonfood items, food labeling, and aerosolized allergens (e.g., in steam from cooking). Furthermore, all patients with IgE-mediated food allergies should be provided with an anaphylaxis emergency action plan and at least one epinephrine autoinjector to treat accidental exposure. In this patient who would like to continue eating seafood, a follow-up evaluation for shellfish tolerance may be considered because the most common allergens in finned fish typically differ from the allergens in shellfish and his skin prick test shows no reactivity to shrimp.

A new treatment approach for food allergies, oral immunotherapy (e.g., for peanut allergy), is currently being researched and consists of the ingestion of increasing doses of the allergen in a controlled setting in order to desensitize the immune system. This approach may allow patients with food allergies to continue eating allergenic foods in the future.

C) INCORRECT:

Some food allergens (especially milk and egg) are tolerated better when they are cooked or heated for a long time. However, there is only limited evidence that seafood boiled for a long time is less allergenic than raw seafood. This approach puts the patient at risk of another life-threatening allergic reaction.

D) INCORRECT:

Although intramuscular epinephrine is used in the management of severe IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., anaphylaxis due to fish allergy), this medication is reserved for emergency situations such as accidental exposure because it carries a high risk of side effects.

E) INCORRECT:

Reducing the amount of fish eaten daily is not an appropriate recommendation in a patient with a history of anaphylaxis caused by fish. This approach is insufficient because allergic reactions are typically triggered by even very small amounts of allergen.
questions.hint: This patient has had an anaphylactic reaction after ingesting fish. His skin prick test confirms a food allergy to salmon and cod. The physician's recommendation should take into account future reactions and potential cross-reactivity.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man with a history of persistent asthma and an episode of severe anaphylaxis after ingesting peanut protein reaches you by phone. He is dining with his wife at a restaurant and, after one bite of his entrée, feels like "something is wrong." He surmises that he inadvertently might have been served food that contains peanuts. He had a positive test for serum immunoglobulin E specific for peanut in the past. He carries oral diphenhydramine and injectable epinephrine with him.
Which one of the following pieces of advice is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Administer self-injectable epinephrine if he sees hives start to develop
Administer self-injectable epinephrine if he feels his throat closing or has difficulty breathing
Take oral diphenhydramine if he sees hives start to develop

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In individuals whose previous allergic reactions were not life-threatening (e.g., involved hives only), it is acceptable to delay the administration of epinephrine until symptoms start and involve at least two systems.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral diphenhydramine is not the initial treatment for impending anaphylaxis, although it may be, and often is, given after epinephrine to relieve itching and hives. Oral diphenhydramine will not prevent the progression of anaphylaxis.

C) INCORRECT:

Critical symptoms of anaphylaxis including respiratory and cardiac arrest can occur within minutes of allergen exposure; thus, waiting to administer epinephrine may increase mortality risk.

D) CORRECT:

All individuals with a history of severe or life-threatening anaphylactic reactions to foods should be counseled to carry self-injectable epinephrine with them at all times. If they inadvertently ingest a food allergen and develop even nonspecific symptoms, such as not feeling right, they should immediately administer the epinephrine and call 911. The epinephrine should be given intramuscularly in the anterolateral thigh using the 1:1000 (1 mg/mL) concentration; the maximum individual dose is 0.3 to 0.5 mL and can be given every 5 to 15 minutes.

Key learning point: When an individual with a history of severe anaphylaxis begins to feel a reaction developing, he or she should immediately administer self-injectable epinephrine and call 911.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral diphenhydramine is not the initial treatment for impending anaphylaxis, although it may be, and often is, given after epinephrine to relieve itching and hives. Oral diphenhydramine will not prevent the progression of anaphylaxis.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man reports having crampy abdominal pain and diarrhea about 3 days per week for the past 3 years. He experiences urgency related to bowel movements, which often relieve the symptoms. He has no melena, hematochezia, weight loss, or other constitutional symptoms. He sees no clear relationship between his symptoms and the timing of meals or specific foods. He has a history of respiratory allergies and was recently evaluated for possible food allergies.
Serum allergen-specific immunoglobulin E testing yields the following results:

Milk <0.35 kU/liter
Wheat 0.69 kU/liter
Soy 0.58 kU/liter

(Normal values would be undetectable for all three measurements.)
Eliminating lactose from the diet for 2 weeks did not affect the severity or frequency of the patient’s symptoms.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hallmarks of immunoglobulin E-mediated food allergy include adverse reactions (e.g., urticaria/angioedema, abdominal pain, and respiratory symptoms) that occur soon after ingestion of a specific food. Without a temporally clear relationship between symptoms and ingestion of a specific food, low serum immunoglobulin E levels have a low predictive value for food allergy.

B) INCORRECT:

Lactose intolerance can produce similar symptoms to those seen in irritable bowel syndrome. However, it is associated with the ingestion of dairy products, and symptoms improve when these products are removed from the diet.

C) CORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome is the most common cause of intermittent, crampy abdominal pain and diarrhea of long-standing duration in an otherwise healthy person without other constitutional or gastrointestinal symptoms.

Key learning point: Low levels of food-specific immunoglobulin E have a predictive value for food allergy that is very low, especially without a temporally clear response to a specific food.

D) INCORRECT:

Hallmarks of immunoglobulin E-mediated food allergy include adverse reactions (e.g., urticaria/angioedema, abdominal pain, and respiratory symptoms) that occur soon after ingestion of a specific food. Without a temporally clear relationship between symptoms and ingestion of a specific food, low serum immunoglobulin E levels have a low predictive value for food allergy.

E) INCORRECT:

Hallmarks of immunoglobulin E-mediated food allergy include adverse reactions (e.g., urticaria/angioedema, abdominal pain, and respiratory symptoms) that occur soon after ingestion of a specific food. Without a temporally clear relationship between symptoms and ingestion of a specific food, low serum immunoglobulin E levels have a low predictive value for food allergy.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man reports intense itching on his tongue and the inside of his mouth after eating refrigerated cantaloupe. He has also experienced similar symptoms after eating watermelon. His medical history is positive for hay fever.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reflux from a pharyngoesophageal diverticulum would not have a specific association with eating melon. It generally causes dysphagia and regurgitation of undigested food hours after ingestion.

B) INCORRECT:

Irritant mucositis is unlikely without a history of irritant exposure.

C) INCORRECT:

Pesticide allergy is unlikely because pesticides (like cosmetics) are tested for their allergenic potential before being brought to market.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has pollen-food allergy syndrome, also called oral allergy syndrome. The condition occurs in individuals with pollen allergies; symptoms begin during or shortly after ingestion of certain foods such as uncooked nuts, vegetables, and fruits. Symptoms include pruritus, tingling, and mild edema that are confined to the oral cavity. In approximately 7% of cases, symptoms progress beyond the mouth. Anaphylaxis is rare and occurs in 1% to 2% of cases.

Oral allergy syndrome is caused by immunoglobulin E-specific cross-reactive epitopes that are shared by both pollens and certain fruits and vegetables. The pollens most frequently associated with this syndrome are birch, which cross-reacts with apples, apricots, and carrots, and ragweed, which cross-reacts with melons.

Key learning point: Individuals with ragweed allergy may experience oral allergy syndrome after the ingestion of melons. This pattern of sensitivity is termed pollen-food allergy syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Cold-induced urticaria occasionally causes mouth itching, but the symptoms would be specific for cold foods and not melons.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man who was recently hospitalized with anaphylaxis after he ingested peanut butter asks for advice about environmental exposures.
Which one of the following scenarios would pose the greatest risk for a severe allergic reaction in this patient?

choices.text: Sitting next to someone who is eating a peanut butter sandwich
Washing off a small amount of peanut butter that accidentally spilled on his hands
Eating pastries from a local bakery that uses peanut flour
Drinking a cup of soy milk
Riding on a plane in which other passengers are eating prepackaged peanuts

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sitting near someone who is eating peanut butter or peanut snacks is unlikely to provoke an allergic reaction.

B) INCORRECT:

Contact on the hands generally produces either a mild local reaction or none at all, unless the peanut butter is ingested or wiped into the eyes.

C) CORRECT:

Peanut allergy is one of the most common food allergies in both children and adults, with reactions ranging from mild hives to severe anaphylaxis. Peanut flour used in a bakery could readily cross-contaminate other food products by surface contamination, leading to inadvertent peanut ingestion and a resulting severe reaction in an allergic person.

Key learning point: The environmental exposure of highest risk to patients with peanut allergy is inadvertent oral exposure to peanuts due to cross-contamination of food.

D) INCORRECT:

Drinking soy milk will not harm a person with a peanut allergy, unless soy allergy is also present.

E) INCORRECT:

Sitting near someone who is eating peanut butter or peanut snacks is unlikely to provoke an allergic reaction.

questions.text:
A 7-week-old boy presents with a 3-week history of loose stools and vomiting. He has been exclusively breastfed since birth, and his mother consumes an unrestricted diet. He initially had yellow stools for the first 4 weeks of life and then began to develop mucus in his stools with occasional flecks of blood. He now has ongoing diarrhea several times daily. He has crying episodes for an hour or so after he eats and large-volume spit-ups.
His length has remained at the 50th percentile since birth. His weight was at the 40th percentile at his 2-week visit but is now at the 25th percentile. The rest of his physical examination is normal. Streaks of red blood are visible in the stool.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease is unlikely in this patient, given that he would have had little to no gluten exposure at this age. Most infant formulas lack gluten.

B) INCORRECT:

Symptomatic Clostridioides difficile infection is unusual in infants. Although they may be colonized with this bacterium, infants rarely present with the classic symptom of C. difficile infection — frequent and sometimes bloody diarrhea in the setting of antibiotic use.

C) INCORRECT:

Lactose intolerance manifests with gastrointestinal symptoms that are similar in some ways to those of allergic proctocolitis, but lactose intolerance is extremely rare in infancy. Lactose intolerance is caused by a diminished level of lactase activity in the small bowel that is either genetic in origin or secondary to intestinal inflammation, for example, after a viral gastroenteritis. Congenital lactase deficiency is a very rare entity that manifests in infancy and is marked by watery diarrhea and failure to thrive. Primary lactase deficiency usually manifests in early childhood but is sometimes not apparent until adulthood. In the United States, lactose intolerance is substantially more common in Black patients and Asian patients than in white patients.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's gastrointestinal symptoms — and the timing of onset in early infancy while he is breastfeeding — suggest a diagnosis of allergic proctocolitis. Breastfed infants can develop an intolerance to cow’s milk protein in breast milk when mothers consume cow’s milk in their diet. Allergic proctocolitis often manifests with gastrointestinal symptoms, such as diarrhea (with the presence of mucus or blood), with variable rates of irritability and vomiting. Diagnosis involves a history suggestive of allergic proctocolitis followed by restriction of maternal diet and then, ideally, confirmation of the diagnosis with failure to tolerate a challenge of the suspect protein.

Key learning point: Allergic proctocolitis can be distinguished from lactose intolerance by the presence of classic gastrointestinal symptoms and onset during early infancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Viral gastroenteritis is associated with vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, but the 3-week duration of symptoms in this patient would be unusual for this diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 4-month-old infant is evaluated for repeated episodes of vomiting and diarrhea. She was breastfed until 3 months of age and then switched to cow’s milk-based formula. The vomiting occurs approximately 2 hours after she drinks formula, and the diarrhea develops approximately 4 hours later. The infant has lost weight in the past 2 weeks.
Which one of the following formulas is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amino acid-based formula is indicated for the limited population of infants with FPIES who do not respond adequately to the use of extensively hydrolyzed formula. The carbohydrate source in amino acid-based formula is glucose polymers, the protein content is individual free amino acids, and the fats are long- and medium-chain triglycerides.

B) INCORRECT:

Whole milk should not be introduced before one year of age, especially in the setting of an infant that is suspected of reacting to milk antigen.

C) CORRECT:

Cow's milk is one of the most common triggers of food protein-induced enterocolitis syndrome (FPIES), a gastrointestinal food hypersensitivity that is not mediated by immunoglobulin E (IgE). FPIES primarily affects infants and typically manifests with vomiting, diarrhea, lethargy, and pallor. It is associated with failure to thrive and may progress to acidemia and shock. Symptoms resolve when the causal protein is removed from the patient’s diet but will recur on repeat exposure.

The best feeding choice for infants with FPIES is extensively hydrolyzed formula because it is considered hypoallergenic and is tolerated by 80% to 90% of these patients. Hydrolyzed formulas are lactose-free; the protein in them is a casein hydrolysate, and the fats are medium- and long-chain triglycerides.

Key learning point: The most appropriate formula for an infant who develops cow’s milk allergy while being fed a cow’s milk-based formula is an extensively hydrolyzed formula.

D) INCORRECT:

Soy-based formula is not recommended for infants with FPIES because a substantial proportion of these patients (40%–60%) may also have sensitivity to soy protein. Soy-based formula is an alternative to cow’s milk-based formula for patients with galactosemia, hereditary lactase deficiency, or IgE-mediated cow’s milk allergy and for parents who prefer a strict vegetarian diet.

E) INCORRECT:

Different cow’s milk formulas are likely to cause the same symptoms as one another, given the presence of similar proteins.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old boy is brought in by his mother, who reports that he has had loose stools for the past month, including some blood-streaked stools in the past week that consist only of liquid. He is breastfed and has been feeding well, about once every 3 hours for roughly 15 minutes on each breast with good latch and transfer. Although he has a history of reflux, there has been an increase recently in small, milk-colored spit-ups after feeds, and he has been fussier than usual. The vomiting is nonprojectile. He has not had any fevers. He has had about six wet diapers of urine per day, which his mother considers to be his normal output. He attends day care.
On examination, he appears comfortable and happy. He has a heart rate of 130 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 80/45 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while breathing ambient air. His abdomen is distended but soft and nontender. His perianal area is erythematous with mild skin breakdown. He has multiple eczematous patches on his trunk and legs.
His stool is positive for occult blood. Viral stool studies are negative.
What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

choices.text: Eliminate milk products from the mother’s diet for at least 2 weeks and reassess
Eliminate milk products from the mother’s diet for 3 days and reassess
Instruct the mother to stop breastfeeding and start formula feeding
Refer to the emergency department for an abdominal radiograph and further infectious workup

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms are consistent with allergic proctocolitis, which is an immunologic and clinical reaction to one or more milk proteins (mainly casein and whey). There are two types of immune-mediated responses:

• Immunoglobulin E (IgE)-mediated immediate hypersensitivity reactions, which are associated with immediate symptoms, including urticaria, angioedema, atopic dermatitis, rhinoconjunctivitis, wheezing, dyspnea, and anaphylaxis
• Non-IgE-mediated, cell-mediated delayed-type reactions, which are associated with atopic dermatitis, food protein-induced enterocolitis syndrome, allergic eosinophilic gastroenteritis, and allergic proctocolitis

These two types of reactions are not always mutually exclusive.

Allergic proctocolitis is estimated to affect 2% to 17% of infants and is more common in formula-fed infants than breastfed infants. Affected children typically present by 6 months of age and then outgrow the intolerance in early childhood. Typical symptoms include frequent regurgitation, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, bloody stools, atopic dermatitis, persistent distress, and colic. In severe cases, patients may develop failure to thrive, anorexia, or hypoalbuminemia. Symptoms concerning for IgE-mediated allergy include acute laryngeal edema, bronchial obstruction, and anaphylaxis. In some cases, the only feature at presentation is iron-deficiency anemia or increased reflux symptoms and colic, which can lead to misdiagnosis.

Allergic proctocolitis can be diagnosed presumptively based on clinical presentation. For a breastfed infant (such as this patient), initial management consists of an elimination diet that involves removing cow’s milk from the mother’s diet; other foods, such as soy, may also need to be eliminated. For a formula-fed infant, initial management involves replacing cow’s milk formula with extensively hydrolyzed formula. Elimination must be sustained for at least 2 weeks (and potentially for as long as 4 weeks) to truly assess symptom improvement. If symptoms improve during the elimination period but then return with the reintroduction of cow’s milk, this is considered diagnostic.

Key learning point: In a breastfed infant with symptoms concerning for allergic proctocolitis, initial management consists of eliminating milk products from the mother’s diet for at least 2 weeks.

B) INCORRECT:

Initiation of a histamine-2-receptor antagonist alone would not improve this patient’s symptoms. Although he has known reflux, his symptoms have increased and changed recently and will presumably improve with the elimination of milk products from his mother’s diet.

C) INCORRECT:

Eliminating cow’s milk for 3 days would not be sufficient for assessing an improvement in symptoms and making the diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Switching from breastfeeding to formula feeding is not necessary in an infant with allergic proctocolitis; elimination of cow’s milk protein from the mother’s diet is usually sufficient to control the symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Referral to the emergency department would be appropriate if this patient were demonstrating signs and symptoms of severe dehydration with hemodynamic instability, but he is not.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl presents for follow-up after a recent visit to the emergency department (ED) for a significant allergic reaction. The father explains that they were eating at a buffet-style seafood restaurant when the child broke out into hives, began to appear uncomfortable, and then vomited and developed swelling of the lips. In the ED, she was noted to have wheezing in addition to the hives and swelling, but her vital signs were stable. She was given oral diphenhydramine, famotidine, and intramuscular epinephrine, and her symptoms rapidly resolved. The hives on her body faded during the next 12 hours. She was hospitalized for overnight observation and was discharged the next morning.
Her medical history is significant for recurrent wheezing with viral infections and moderate eczema. Her father notes that he has a peanut allergy, so he and his wife have not given her any foods that they consider to be allergenic.
In the office today, the girl is happy and playful. She has a heart rate of 90 beats per minute and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. Her body weight is 16 kg (50th percentile for age). She has moderate atopic dermatitis on her face and flexural areas.
In addition to referral to an allergy specialist, which one of the following next steps is most important for this patient at this time?

choices.text: Obtain a careful history of what was served at the restaurant and what the child touched and ate, and prescribe an epinephrine autoinjector at a dose of 0.15 mg
Order blood immunoglobulin G testing for food allergies, and prescribe an epinephrine autoinjector at a dose of 0.3 mg
Recommend that the child avoid CT scans with iodinated contrast, given possible cross-reactivity with a shellfish allergy, and prescribe an epinephrine autoinjector at a dose of 0.3 mg
Order blood immunoglobulin E testing for food allergies, and prescribe an epinephrine autoinjector at a dose of 0.15 mg
Recommend that the child be placed on a diet of elemental formula and that the parents avoid introducing any foods into her diet for 6 months

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Food allergy affects up to 6% of all children younger than age 5 — and up to 35% of children under age 5 who have moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis (as in this case). The most common food allergens are milk, eggs, peanuts, tree nuts, crustacean shellfish, fish, wheat, and soy. Allergies to milk, egg, soy, and wheat tend to manifest in infancy but will often remit by adulthood. In contrast, allergies to peanuts, tree nuts, crustacean shellfish, and fish often manifest later and are less likely to remit over time.

In this case, the specific cause of the patient's allergic reaction is unknown, so the first step is to document what was being served in the restaurant at the time of the reaction and what the patient may have touched or eaten. The results of this history will help determine the specific tests that the child should undergo and also which foods she should avoid while awaiting definitive testing.

The two types of tests that are commonly performed to evaluate possible food allergies are skin-prick testing and immunoglobulin E (IgE) blood testing.

• Skin-prick testing involves introducing a tiny amount of antigen (an extract of purified food) into the epidermis. When done correctly, this type of testing has a sensitivity of 85% and a specificity of 74%. The results are immediate, making it a preferred test among many allergists.
• IgE blood testing measures the presence of IgE to specific food antigens. The sensitivity and specificity are similar to that of skin-prick testing, but the results can take several days to arrive.

Skin-prick testing and IgE blood testing may eventually be appropriate for this child, but a careful history must be obtained first, to ensure that the testing is as targeted as possible. Given the relatively low specificity of these tests, evaluating large panels of foods without a targeted approach would likely result in false-positive results and thus unnecessary limits to the child's diet. These limits are not without consequence: Milk avoidance in childhood has been shown to increase the likelihood of osteopenia in teenagers, and peanut avoidance during the first 5 years of life in children with eczema has been shown to increase the risk for peanut allergy.

Children with a history of significant allergic reactions, as in this case, should be prescribed an epinephrine autoinjector. The recommended dose of epinephrine for the autoinjector, according to the American Academy of Pediatrics, is 0.15 mg for children who weigh 15 to 25 kg (as in this case) and 0.3 mg for those who weigh ≥25 kg.

Children and their parents should be given detailed instructions and a trainer demonstration to learn how to use the autoinjector. They should be counseled to administer the epinephrine immediately upon symptom onset, as the main factor reported in most fatal cases of anaphylaxis is delayed use of intramuscular epinephrine. Epinephrine should be kept at a comfortable temperature range similar to that of the human body; storage in a hot car or in a refrigerator is not advisable.

Key learning point: When a child weighing 15 to 25 kg requires an epinephrine autoinjector for treatment of anaphylaxis, the appropriate dose of the epinephrine is 0.15 mg.

B) INCORRECT:

Immunoglobulin G (IgG) testing has no role in the diagnosis of food allergy, as IgG does not contribute to mast-cell activation or allergic symptoms. However, patients are often exposed to internet-based marketing for these tests and may inquire about them.

Children with a history of significant allergic reactions, as in this case, should be prescribed an epinephrine autoinjector. The recommended dose of epinephrine for the autoinjector, according to the American Academy of Pediatrics, is 0.15 mg for children who weigh 15 to 25 kg (as in this case) and 0.3 mg for those who weigh ≥25 kg.

C) INCORRECT:

The idea that patients with shellfish allergy should avoid radiographic contrast media is a myth. Shellfish allergy does not cause a cross-reactive allergic reaction to iodine contrast. Furthermore, although this patient was eating in a seafood restaurant when her allergic reaction occurred, it would be premature to assume that shellfish caused her reaction.

Children with a history of significant allergic reactions, as in this case, should be prescribed an epinephrine autoinjector. The recommended dose of epinephrine for the autoinjector, according to the American Academy of Pediatrics, is 0.15 mg for children who weigh 15 to 25 kg (as in this case) and 0.3 mg for those who weigh ≥25 kg.

D) INCORRECT:

The two types of tests that are commonly performed to evaluate possible food allergies are skin-prick testing and immunoglobulin E (IgE) blood testing. However, skin-prick testing and IgE blood testing may eventually be appropriate for this child, but a careful history must be obtained first, to ensure that the testing is as targeted as possible. Given the relatively low specificity of these tests, evaluating large panels of foods without a targeted approach would likely result in false-positive results and thus unnecessary limits to the child's diet.

Children with a history of significant allergic reactions, as in this case, should be prescribed an epinephrine autoinjector. The recommended dose of epinephrine for the autoinjector, according to the American Academy of Pediatrics, is 0.15 mg for children who weigh 15 to 25 kg (as in this case) and 0.3 mg for those who weigh ≥25 kg.

E) INCORRECT:

A diet of elemental formula is sometimes used to treat symptoms of eosinophilic esophagitis, but it is not used to evaluate or treat food allergies. It is appealing to many parents and clinicians, particularly in younger children, but is not ideal because it results in complete elimination of solid-food consumption.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl is seen for follow-up after a recent hospitalization for anaphylaxis related to ingestion of peanut butter. Her mother asks for advice about environmental exposures.
Which one of the following scenarios would pose the greatest risk for a severe allergic reaction in this patient?

choices.text: Riding on a plane in which other passengers are eating prepackaged peanuts
Washing off a small amount of peanut butter that accidentally spilled on her hands
Sitting next to someone who is eating a peanut butter sandwich
Eating pastries from a local bakery that uses peanut flour
Drinking a cup of soy milk

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sitting near someone who is eating peanut snacks is unlikely to provoke an allergic reaction.

B) INCORRECT:

Contact on the hands generally produces either a mild local reaction or none at all, unless the peanut butter is ingested or wiped into the eyes.

C) INCORRECT:

Sitting near someone who is eating peanut butter is unlikely to provoke an allergic reaction.

D) CORRECT:

Peanut allergy is one of the most common food allergies in children, with reactions ranging from mild hives to severe anaphylaxis. Peanut flour used in a bakery could readily cross-contaminate other food products by surface contamination, leading to inadvertent peanut ingestion and a resulting severe reaction in an allergic person.

Key learning point: The environmental exposure of highest risk to patients with peanut allergy is inadvertent oral exposure to peanuts due to cross-contamination of food.

E) INCORRECT:

Drinking soy milk will not harm a person with a peanut allergy, unless soy allergy is also present.

questions.text: A previously healthy 35-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation because of an episode of shortness of breath and swollen lips 2 weeks ago. Ten minutes after he started eating seafood, he noticed a swelling of the lips, wheezing, and shortness of breath. He had to be transported to the emergency department for treatment and close observation after this episode. A skin prick test shows a positive result for salmon and cod; there is no reactivity to shrimp. The patient enjoys eating seafood and wonders whether he can continue to eat other types of fish in the future. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation?

choices.text: Take antihistamines one hour before eating fish
Inject intramuscular norepinephrine after eating fish
Reduce the daily dietary amount of fish

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral antihistamines can be used to treat mild allergic reactions such as urticaria, oral itch, or mild abdominal pain. This patient, however, had an anaphylactic reaction, for which treatment with antihistamines is insufficient. Furthermore, there is no recommendation that supports pretreatment with antihistamines in patients with IgE-mediated food allergies (e.g., fish allergy).

B) CORRECT:

Complete avoidance of the food allergen and similar foods is the preferred management for patients with food allergies. Although this patient's skin prick test is positive only for salmon and cod, he should also avoid all other types of finned fish because of a high risk of cross-reactivity. In addition, he should be counseled on cross-contacts (e.g., in restaurants), food allergens in unexpected sources or nonfood items, food labeling, and aerosolized allergens (e.g., in steam from cooking). Furthermore, all patients with IgE-mediated food allergies should be provided with an anaphylaxis emergency action plan and at least one epinephrine autoinjector to treat accidental exposure. In this patient who would like to continue eating seafood, a follow-up evaluation for shellfish tolerance may be considered because the most common allergens in finned fish typically differ from the allergens in shellfish and his skin prick test shows no reactivity to shrimp.

A new treatment approach for food allergies, oral immunotherapy (e.g., for peanut allergy), is currently being researched and consists of the ingestion of increasing doses of the allergen in a controlled setting in order to desensitize the immune system. This approach may allow patients with food allergies to continue eating allergenic foods in the future.

C) INCORRECT:

Some food allergens (especially milk and egg) are tolerated better when they are cooked or heated for a long time. However, there is only limited evidence that seafood boiled for a long time is less allergenic than raw seafood. This approach puts the patient at risk of another life-threatening allergic reaction.

D) INCORRECT:

Although intramuscular epinephrine is used in the management of severe IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., anaphylaxis due to fish allergy), this medication is reserved for emergency situations such as accidental exposure because it carries a high risk of side effects.

E) INCORRECT:

Reducing the amount of fish eaten daily is not an appropriate recommendation in a patient with a history of anaphylaxis caused by fish. This approach is insufficient because allergic reactions are typically triggered by even very small amounts of allergen.
questions.hint: This patient has had an anaphylactic reaction after ingesting fish. His skin prick test confirms a food allergy to salmon and cod. The health care provider's recommendation should take into account future reactions and potential cross-reactivity.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of breathing difficulty, lip swelling, and a raised, blotchy rash over much of his body. The symptoms began about 10 minutes after he ate a peanut butter sandwich. He appears anxious. There is no prior history of similar episodes. Examination shows widespread erythema and mild wheezing.


Blood pressure
90/60 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
30/min


What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute asthma presents with wheezing and respiratory distress but lacks systemic allergic features such as rash and lip swelling. The rapid onset after allergen ingestion and associated hypotension suggest a systemic allergic reaction, not isolated asthma.

B) INCORRECT:

Isolated urticaria involves a raised, blotchy rash confined to the skin without systemic involvement. The presence of lip swelling, wheezing, and hypotension indicates a systemic reaction, not limited to the skin, ruling out isolated urticaria.

C) INCORRECT:

Allergic rhinitis primarily presents with nasal symptoms such as congestion, rhinorrhea, and sneezing, typically triggered by airborne allergens. It does not cause systemic symptoms like hypotension, widespread rash, or respiratory distress, which are present here.

D) CORRECT:

Anaphylaxis is a severe, systemic IgE-mediated reaction that occurs rapidly after exposure to an allergen. It manifests with symptoms such as widespread erythema, lip swelling, wheezing, and hypotension. These symptoms result from mast cell degranulation and the release of mediators like histamine, leading to vasodilation and increased vascular permeability. The acute onset of multisystem involvement, including cutaneous, respiratory, and cardiovascular symptoms, following allergen ingestion is characteristic of anaphylaxis. Prompt recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent progression to life-threatening complications.

Key learning point: Anaphylaxis in children is often triggered by food allergies, presenting with symptoms like difficulty breathing, lip swelling, and widespread rash.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 2 hours after eating shellfish at a restaurant. She reports generalized itching and notes that her face feels "puffy." Physical examination shows diffuse urticaria on her arms and trunk, mild bilateral periorbital edema, and normal lung sounds. Vital signs are BP, 128/82 mm Hg; P, 88; R, 18; oxygen saturation, 99% on room air. She reports no difficulty breathing or swallowing and denies nausea or abdominal pain. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with localized allergic reaction manifesting as urticaria and mild angioedema without systemic involvement. The absence of cardiovascular compromise, respiratory symptoms, or gastrointestinal involvement indicates this does not meet criteria for anaphylaxis. Second-generation antihistamines like cetirizine are the first-line treatment for histamine-mediated allergic reactions presenting with urticaria and mild angioedema.

B) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine is indicated for anaphylaxis, which requires involvement of two or more organ systems or isolated cardiovascular compromise. This patient has only dermatologic manifestations with stable vital signs and no respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms, so epinephrine is not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Albuterol is a bronchodilator used for respiratory symptoms such as wheezing or bronchospasm. This patient has normal lung sounds and no respiratory complaints, making albuterol inappropriate for this presentation.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic corticosteroids like prednisone may be considered as adjunctive therapy in severe urticaria exacerbations, but they are not first-line treatment and are typically used in consultation with a specialist.

E) INCORRECT:

Famotidine is an H2 receptor antagonist that may have a role as adjunctive therapy in allergic reactions, but it is not first-line treatment for urticaria and angioedema.
